title: Understanding Hydrogen Sorption in In-
-MOF: A Charged Metal-Organic Framework with Open-Metal Sites, Narrow Channels, and Counterions
abstract: The hydrogen sorption mechanism in the metal−organic framework (MOF) In-
-MOF was elucidated using our grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations that include explicit many-body polarization interactions.
Grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulations of hydrogen sorption were performed in In-
-MOF, a charged metal–organic framework (MOF) that contains In

O trimers coordinated to 5,5′-azobis(1,3-benzenedicarboxylate) linkers. The MOF contains nitrate counterions that are located in carcerand-like capsules of the framework. This MOF was shown to have a high hydrogen uptake at 77 K and 1.0 atm. The simulations were performed with a potential that includes explicit many-body polarization interactions, which were important for modeling gas sorption in a charged/polar MOF such as In-
-MOF. The simulated hydrogen sorption isotherms were in good agreement with experiment in this challenging platform for modeling. The simulations predict a high initial isosteric heat of adsorption,
, which is in contrast to the experimental value of 6.5 kJ mol
for all loadings. The difference in the

behavior between experiment and simulation is attributed to the fact that, in experimental measurements, the sorbate molecules cannot access the isolated cages containing the nitrate ions, the most energetically favorable site in the MOF, at low pressures due to an observed diffusion barrier. In contrast, the simulations were able to capture the sorption of hydrogen onto the nitrate ions at low loading due to the equilibrium nature of GCMC simulations. The experimental
values were reproduced in simulation by blocking access to all of the nitrate ions in the MOF. Furthermore, at 77 K, the sorbed hydrogen molecules were reminiscent of a dense fluid in In-
-MOF starting at approximately 5.0 atm, and this was verified by monitoring the isothermal compressibility, β
, values. The favorable sites for hydrogen sorption were identified from the polarization distribution as the nitrate ions, the In

O trimers, and the azobenzene nitrogen atoms. Lastly, the two-dimensional quantum rotational levels for a hydrogen molecule sorbed about the aforementioned sites were calculated and the transitions were in good agreement with those that were observed in the experimental inelastic neutron scattering spectra.
text: The use of molecular hydrogen as an alternative fuel source is dependent on the development of new materials that can effectively store large quantities of hydrogen through a physisorption process under near-ambient conditions.
Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are a class of solid crystalline materials that have been considered to be promising for this particular task.
These materials are synthesized with rigid organic ligands coordinated to metal-ion clusters.
They are inherently modular, as a variety of different MOFs can be synthesized by simply tuning the organic ligand and/or metal ion.
The overall structure of MOFs is characterized by a porous three-dimensional network that can be used to sorb guest molecules, such as H
O trimer building block and 5,5′-azobis(1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid) (ABBDC) linkers that resulted in a porous material with an ionic framework and narrow channels.

In this work, grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulations were performed to investigate hydrogen sorption in In-
-MOF. This was done in an attempt to understand the sorption mechanism in this MOF. GCMC methods allow simulated hydrogen sorption isotherms and associated isosteric heats of adsorption,
, values to be compared to those that were measured experimentally.
Accurate molecular level predictions of gas sorption in MOFs is predicated upon obtaining outstanding agreement with experimental results. By examining H
-MOF, we hope to better characterize H
sorption in the material and elucidate the sorption mechanism.

-MOF is a highly charged/polar MOF due to the presence of the indium open-metal sites and nitrate counterions. Indeed, polarization interactions have been shown to be necessary for modeling gas sorption in this MOF.
Note, other previous simulation studies on In-
-MOF have not included the role that polarization plays on hydrogen sorption in this material.
As a consequence, the simulated hydrogen sorption isotherms and

values in those studies were observed to underestimate experimental measurements. Explicit polarization interactions cannot be neglected when considering high-density hydrogen interacting with highly charged/polar MOFs. A theoretical study that introduced insights into the importance of polarization in In-
-MOF was performed by Belof et al. in 2007 through canonical Monte Carlo (CMC) methods.
The study demonstrated that polarization effects were critical to capture the sorption of hydrogen onto the charged moieties in the MOF, particularly the open-metal sites provided by the In

O trimers. The work presented here demonstrates that quantitative modeling of sorption processes is possible using models that are carefully constructed (from gas phase data) and that include explicit induction. The early CMC study used a simple model to demonstrate the essential chemical physics of sorption in such materials.

Furthermore, the studies demonstrated that introducing induced dipole interactions were required to capture the loading of hydrogen onto the open-metal sites provided by the copper paddlewheel, [Cu
], clusters. As another example, recent molecular dynamics (MD) simulation studies on water sorption in the flexible MOF, MIL-53(Cr),
showed that polarization interactions were required for the formation of hydrogen bonds between the water molecules and the hydroxyl groups in the MOF.

Note, any difference in the rotational tunneling transitions between experiment and theory could be attributed to the nature of the potential energy surface used in this work and the fact that the theoretical positions of the H

In conclusion, we performed simulations of hydrogen sorption in In-
